>When B calls C, is B's method trivial? =
See the JUnit FAQ for details on
>what
>I mean by that. If B's method is tr=
ivial, then testing B only tests C and
>nothing else, so I wouldn't bother =
writing the test. If B's method takes
>parameters and passes them to C, the=
n B's method still cannot break: only
>the methods that call B's method and=
 C could break, so test those.
>
>I would use the same approach for the rel=
ationship between A and B.
>
>If B's method is not trivial, then as soon as=
 you feel the pain of
>duplicated tests mock the behavior in C that B calls=
 and use that mock
>behavior in the test. This allows you to test B in isol=
ation from any
>defects in C.
>
>I hope this helps.
>
